plain: The user's favourite genre is probably LGBT fiction, as "Tales of the City" and "A Boy's Own Story" are both considered classics in that genre. The user's favourite kind of plot is probably character-driven, as both "Tales of the City" and "To Kill a Mockingbird" focus heavily on the development of their protagonists. The user's favourite setting is probably urban, as both "Tales of the City" and "The No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency" take place in cities. The user's favourite writing style is probably stream-of-consciousness, as "Tales of the City" and "A Boy's Own Story" both use this technique extensively. The user's favourite length is probably novella or novel, as all of the user's favourite books fall into those categories. The user's favourite topic is probably coming-of-age, as both "Tales of the City" and "A Boy's Own Story" deal with this theme. The user's favourite pacing is probably slow, as both "Tales of the City" and "To Kill a Mockingbird" take their time developing their stories. The user's favourite narrative structure is probably first-person, as both "Tales of the City" and "To Kill a Mockingbird" are told from the perspective of their protagonists. The user's favourite themes are probably identity and community, as both "Tales of the City" and "To Kill a Mockingbird" explore these concepts in depth.
